item.title: Baire properties
item.description:

If has no isolated points and is finite then is nowhere dense
If is meagre then is meagre

If is a sequence of comeagre sets then is comeagre

item.title: Baire space
item.description:
Let be a topological space.
We call a Baire space if TFES hold:

Every meagre set has empty interior, i.e.
Every countable union of nowhere dense sets has empty interior
Every countable union of closed nowhere dense sets has empty interior
Every comeagre set is dense, i.e.
Every countable intersection of dense interior sets is dense
Every countable intersection of open dense sets is dense
Every nonempty open set is nonmeagre
The above also implies

Every countable union of nowhere dense sets has empty interior
is nonmeagre, i.e.
any countable family of (closed) nowhere dense sets cannot cover

item.title: Classification of critical points of ODE
item.description:
Consider , where is .
Let
Let be the set of solutions defined on some initial time.
Suppose is a critical point, i.e. , i.e. is an equilibrium solution.

isolated: there are no critical points in
stable (S): if then exists and .
attractive: if then
asymptotically stable (AS): is stable and attractive
unstable (US): it is not stable
node (N): exactly tangents at where all non-equilibrium trajectories are tangent to one of them
proper node (PN): all trajectories have a tangent at
improper node (IN): all trajectories have the same tangent at and pass through distinct quadrants
saddle point (Sa): all non-equilibrium trajectories are repelled by
spiral point (Sp): all trajectories spiral into or out of passing through all quadrants
center (C): all trajectories periodically orbit around in an ellipse
item.guid: Math/Classification of critical points of ODE.md

Experiement

The first ball has choices, then the second has etc.
Permute objects with , but the last objects' permutations do not affect the first , thus we overcounted permutations

The estimation error is caused by estimating expected risk with emprical risk
The approximation error is caused by approximating the space of all predictors with only our models

sometimes add the momentum term to avoid getting stuck in local minima, i.e. with

To find , we use the delta rule:

where

Notice depends on downstream weights, so we have to compute and update each weight upstream

First, notation:

An image is a 2D matrix of pixels
A receptive field of an image is a patch of pixels, usually rectangular
A filter/kernel is a map (matrix of weights) running through every receptive field in the image, resulting in a weighted sum over each patch
The stride of a filter is the number of pixels it moves in each direction when shifting through the image
The zero-padding of a filter is the number of extra pixels we consider outside the image when applying the filter.
In a convolution neural network, we can visualize

Each layer as a stack of images, each pixel on the image is a neuron
A feature map mapping all images in a layer to one sheet of the next layer
The map consists of one kernel/filter for each image in the stack, which can be different or the same (called parameter sharing, can reduce number of weights)
The sum of all the results of the filters gives the value for the next layer, therefore we only need one bias term (instead of one for each filter)
Each feature map (thus each sheet of the next layer) represents one feature of the images, e.g. vertical lines, horizontal lines, etc.
See Python tensorflow for coding

An matrix is a rectangular layout of objects with m rows and n rows.

The following 3 operations on the matrix are called elementary row operations:

: Swap row and row
: Multiply row by a non-zero scalar
: Add row 's onto row
Note that these are equivalent to left-multiplying with the respective elementary matrix

The following 3 operations on the matrix are called elementary column operations:

: Swap column and column
: Multiply column by a non-zero scalar
: Add column 's onto column Note that these are equivalent to right-multiplying with the respective elementary matrix.

item.title: probability space
item.description:
Let be a measure space.
We call a probability space if .
In this case, we call a probability measure
In probability theory, the measure space take on a special meaning:

is the sample space, the set of all possible outcomes
is an event, a collection of some outcomes
is the event space, the set of all events that can occur
is the probability, measuring the likeliness of an event
Some special events also gets different interpretations:

and are mutally exclusive if
is mutually exclusive if the elements are pairwise disjoint
is exhaustive if it covers , i.e.
The axioms of sigma-algebra of sets also get an interpretation:

Exhaustive outcomes: , that is at least one outcome must happen
Mutually exclusive outcomes: , that is if we know an outcome happened, we must also know that none of the outcomes of the event can happen
Countable union: disjoint , that is if we know distinct outcomes happened, the event is possible
Finally, the probability as a measure get an interpretation:

sigma-additivity: If we have a sequence of mutually exclusive events , then
range: , so some outcome must happen
Recall that measures are monotone, countably subadditive, and has properties in Measure continuity

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt plt.plot(x,y,linespec,label='f') # plots y against x given size(x)=size(y) plt.scatter(x,y,color='r',marker='x') # plots points (x_n,y_n) given size(x)=size(y) plt.hist(x, bins=<num>) # histogram plt.imshow(image, cmap=?) # actually plots the pixels, choose ? to be matplotlib.cm.binary, matplotlib. plt.savefig('name.png') # saves figure as file Curve template: t = linspace() x = f(t) y = g(x) plot(x, y) Scatter template: p = np.array([[x1,y1],[x2,y2],[x3,y3]]) plt.scatter(p[:,0],p[:,1],color='b',marker='o') Plot options: % put after the plt.plot(x,y) command plt.xlim([a,b]) plt.ylim([c,d]) plt.xlabel('x') plt.ylabel('y') plt.title('Title') plt.legend() # show legend according to the label argument in plt.plot # plt.legend(loc='best') gives best location Subplot: fig = plt.figure(figsize=[a,b]) # inches fig.add_subplot(m,n,1); plt.plot(...) fig.add_subplot(m,n,2); plt.plot(...) fig.add_subplot(m,n,[3,4]); plt.plot(...)

from mpl_toolkits.mplot3d import Axes3D u = linspace() v = linspace() (U,V) = np.meshgrid(u,v) X = f(U,V) Y = g(U,V) Z = h(U,V) mesh(X,Y,Z) fig = plt.figure() ax = Axes3D(fig) ax.plot_surface(X,Y,Z) ax.set_xlabel('x') ax.set_ylabel('y') ax.set_zlabel('z')

item.title: Python tensorflow
item.description:
import tensorflow as tf


from tensorflow import keras keras.layers.Dense(<num>, activation='...') # adds a dense layer, i.e. fully connected neurons # <num>: number of neurons # activation: 'relu', 'tanh', 'logistic', nothing for no activation function (usually at output layer) keras.layers.Flatten(input_shape=[x,y]) # adds a flattens layer: flattens a 2D array into a 1D array, useful for images keras.layers.Conv2D(filters=256, kernel_size=3, strides=1, activation='...', padding='...') # adds a convolutional layer # filters: number of feature maps # kernel_size: n by n filters # strides: number of pixels shifted per move of the filters # activation: 'relu', 'tanh', 'logistic' # padding: 'same', 'valid' # same: pads ceil(image/strides) zero-pixels along each direction, when odd add one in the end # valid: no padding, ignore neurons when not enough to apply filter keras.layers.MaxPooling2D(m,n) # adds a pooling layer using max pooling, condenses each m by n rectangle into 1 neuron according to their max

from tensorflow import keras model = keras.models.Sequential([<layer1>, <layer2>, ...]) # Constructs the framework of a model model.add(<layer>) # Adds <layer> to model model.summary() # Gives summary of a model layers = model.layers # array of all layers hidden1 = layers[1] (w,b) = hidden1.get_weights() model.compile(loss='...',optimizer='...') # Specifies how the model finds the weights # loss: 'mean_squared_error', 'binary_crossentropy' # optimizer: 'sgd' X = <data> y = <targets> # checkpoint_cb = keras.callbacks.ModelCheckpoint("cp_cb.h5) history = model.fit(X,y,epochs=100) # optionally add callbacks=[checkpoint_cb] to save checkpoints pd.DataFrame(history.history).plot() # useful for plotting the mean error x = <input> y_pred = model.predict(x) model.evaluate(X_test, y_test) model.save("filename.h5") # saves in HDF5 format model = keras.models.load_model("filename.h5") # loads model

from tensorflow import keras model = keras.models.Sequential() model.add(keras.layers.Flatten(input_shape=[x,y])) # for image data model.add(keras.layers.Dense(300,activation='relu')) model.add(keras.layers.Dense(100,activation='relu')) model.add(keras.layers.Dense(1))

from tensorflow import keras model = keras.models.Sequential([ keras.layers.Flatten(input_shape=[x,y]) # for image data keras.layers.Dense(300,activation='relu') keras.layers.Dense(100,activation='relu') keras.layers.Dense(1,activation='sigmoid') ])

from tensorflow import keras model = keras.models.Sequential([ keras.layers.Conv2D(64,7,activation="relu",padding="same",input_shape=[28,28,1]), keras.layers.MaxPooling2D(2,2), keras.layers.Conv2D(128,3,activation="relu",padding="same"), keras.layers.Conv2D(128,3,activation="relu",padding="same"), keras.layers.MaxPooling2D(2,2), keras.layers.Conv2D(256,3,activation="relu",padding="same"), keras.layers.Conv2D(256,3,activation="relu",padding="same"), keras.layers.MaxPooling2D(2,2), keras.layers.Flatten(), keras.layers.Dense(128,activation="relu"), keras.layers.Dense(64,activation="relu"), keras.layers.Dense(1,activation="sigmoid") ])

Valid variable names must start with letter, contain only letter,digit,underscores, and cannot be a reserved keyword
Case sensitive

a = [a1, a2, a3]
A = [a11, a12; a21, a22]
a(i)
a([i1, i2, i3])
A(i,j)
A([i1, i2], [j1, j2, j3])
end the last index
: [1,...,end]

Assignment of multiple elements work as long as dimensions match
a(j)=[] removes the entry
A(:,j)=[] removes the -th column
Whenever possible, MATLAB will extend the array size in order to assign an object there
a = [1,...,10] and a(20)=20 will give you a 1x20 array

zeros(m,n) ones(m,n) eye(m,n) zeros(n) ones(n) eye(n) magic(n) hilb(n) diag(v,k) diag(A,k) tril(A,k) triu(A,k) start:step:stop % arithmetic sequence from <start> to <stop> inclusive with <step> as common difference linspace(start,stop,step) % array of num evenly spaced points from start to stop inclusive [X,Y] = meshgrid(x,y) % X is length(y) rows of x and Y is length(x) many columns of y. More precisely: X_ij=x_j, Y_ij=y_i, size(X)=(length(x),length(y)), size(Y)=(length(y),length(x)) length(v) size(A) numel(A) repelem(v,k) repelem(v,[k1,...,kn]) repelem(A,m,n) repmat(A,m,n) repmat(A,n) fliplr(A) flipud(A) rot90(A,k) paddata(A,m) trimdata(A,m) resize(A,m) reshape(A,sz) (must have prod(sz)=numel(A), use [] on one arguement to auto-calculate dimension) blkdiag(A1,...,An) horzcat(A1,...,An) == [A1,...,An] vertcat(A1,...,An) == [A1;...;An] dot(v,w) cross(v,w) A+B A-B A.*B A./B % pointwise A+v A-v A.*v A./v % each row/column of A will do the operation with v pointwise A+a A-a A.*a A./a % each entry of A will do the operation with a pointwise a*A % scalar multiplication A*B % matrix multiplication, requires matching dimensions, alt: mtimes(A,B) A^n % matrix power, requires square matrix, alt: mpower(A,n) A^(1/2) % matrix square root, alt: sqrtm(A) A.' % transpose, alt: transpose(A) A' % conjugate transpose, alt: ctranspose(A) A\B % solves AX=B, alt: mldivide(A,B)) A/B % solves YB=A, alt: mrdivide(A,B) linsolve(A,B) % solves AX=B expm(A) logm(A) det(A) trace(A) inv(A) adjoint(A) % classical adjoint rref(A) rank(A) null(A) % orthonormal basis for null space null(A,'r') % rational orthonormal basis orth(A) % orthonormal basis for column space spy(A) % visualize the pattern of nonzero entries of A v = eig(A) % vector of eigenvalues of A [V,D] = eig(A) % diagonalization eigs(A) % vector of eigenvalues of A ordered by descending absolute values eigs(A,k) % first k elements of eigs(A) v = svd(A) % vector of singular values of A [U,D,V] = svd(A) % singular value decomposition norm(A) % spectral norm max(svd(A)) cond(A) % conditional number max(svd(A))/min(svd(A)) [V,D] = eig(A) % D=inv(V)AV if diagonalizable [L,U,P] = lu(A) % PA=LU [Q,R] = qr(A) % A=QR [Q,R,P] = qr(A) % PA=QR U = chol(A) % A=U'U L = chol(A,'lower') % A=LL' [U,D,V] = svd(A) % A=UVD' istril(A) istriu(A) isdiag(A) issymmetric(A) ishermitian(A)
Most functions in Math functions works on arrays pointwisely

diary mydiary diary off diary on type diary clear % clears all variable clear var % clears the variable var who % list all variables who a* % list variable starting with a whos % list all variable names, size, type whos var % list the name, size, type of var

disp(a) disp(v) disp('str') [str1, str2, ...] % concatenates strings {str1, str2, ...} % multiline string <dtype>(<var>) % converts var into type dtype num2str(<num>) logical(<num>) % true iff num is nonzero logical(<arr>) % true iff all entries are true % logical('') and logical([]) return false % logical(NaN) throws an error any(v) % true if at least one true any(A) % returns row vector of any() of columns of A, that is [any(A1), any(A2),...] all(v) % true if all entries true all(A) % returns row vector of all() of columns of A, that is [all(A1), all(A2),...] < <= > >= == ~= & relational operator && || ~ & logical operator v==a % returns an array w with w_i=(v_i==a) A==B % returns an matrix C with C_ij=(A_ij==B_ij) isequal(A,B) or logical(A==B) % returns true when A=B as matrices logical(A~=B) % returns true when any entry is different ~isequal(A,B) or ~logical(A==B) % returns true when A not equal B as matrices find(v) % returns all true entries find(v,n) % returns the first n true entries find(v,n,'last') % returns the last n true entries find(v==0) % true entries of v==0, i.e. all zero entries find(v>1) % etc. if cond1 % forces logical(cond1) if var is not true/false statement1a; statement1b; elseif cond2 statement2a; statement2b; else statement3a; statement3b end for k = <arr> statement1; statement2; end for <cond> statement1; statement2; end

plot(x,y,linespec) % plots y against x given size(x)=size(y) plot(x1,y1,linespec1,x2,y2,linespec2,...) % for multiple curves in same graph plot(X,Y)==plot(X(:,1),Y(:,1),X(:,2),Y(:,2),...) % plots columns of Y against columns of X plot(y,linespec) % plots y against 1:length(y) plot(Y) % plots columns of Y against 1:length(y) plot(z) % plot Im(z) against Re(z) quiver(X,Y,V,W) % vector field, draws arrows from (X_ij, Y_ij) to ((X+V)_ij, (Y+W)_ij) With the same syntax as above, we have: loglog(x,y) % log y against log x semilogx(x,y) % y against log x semilogy(x,y) % log y against x polarplot(theta,r) % polar fill(x,y,<color>) % fill polygon (convex hull) bar(x,y) % bar graph, bar(y) gives one bar per element barh(x,y) % horizontal bar graph pie(x,{'label1','label2',...}) % pie chart, labels optional Curve template: t = linspace() x = f(t) y = g(x) plot(x, y) Vector field template: x = linspace() y = linspace() [X,Y] = meshgrid(x,y) V = f(X,Y) W = g(X,Y) quiver(X,Y,V,W) Plot options: % Put after the plot(x,y) command axis([a,b,c,d]) % or xlim([a,b]);ylim([c,d]) % or axis square/equal xlabel('x') ylabel('y') title('Title') text(<pos_x>,<pos_y>,{'text', 'multiline'}) legend('y=f(x)') grid on/off box on/off Line properties: % replace plot(x,y) with this plot(x, y, 'ro:', ... 'LineWidth',3, ... 'MarkerEdgeColor','k', ... 'MarkerFaceColor',[.49 1 .63],... 'MarkerSize',12) Text options: % replace any text function with this legend('y=f(x)',... 'FontSize', 16,... 'FontWeight', 'bold',... 'Color', 'r') Holding: % plots multiple in one graph hold on plot(...) plot(...) hold off Figures: fig = figure(n) % Initialize n-th figure window, automatically generates n if no args given plot(...) % plot on n-th figure window figure(n) % shows n-th figure window (if defined) saveas(fig, 'name', 'png') close n % close figure n window close all Subplot: figure subplot(m,n,1); plot(...) subplot(m,n,2); plot(...) subplot(m,n,[3,4]); plot(...)

plot3(x,y,z) % joins the points (x_i, y_i, z_i) text(x(i), y(i), z(i), 'i-th point') % useful label mesh(X,Y,Z) % parametric surface of z_ij as height function of (x_ij,y_ij) surf(X,Y,Z) % mesh but solid face colors bar3(Z) % 3D bar graph barh3(Z) % 3D horizontal bar graph stem3(x,y,z) ribbon(t,z) waterfall(Z) 3D curve template: t = linspace() x = f(t) y = g(t) z = h(t) plot3(x,y,z) 3D surface template: u = linspace() v = linspace() [U,V] = meshgrid(u,v) X = f(U,V) Y = g(U,V) Z = h(U,V) mesh(X,Y,Z) Plot options: % Put after the plot command axis([a,b,c,d,e,f]) % or xlim([a,b]);ylim([c,d]);zlim([e,f]) % or axis square/equal xlabel('x') ylabel('y') zlabel('z') title('Title') text(<pos_x>,<pos_y>,{'text', 'multiline'}) legend('y=f(x)') grid on/off box on/off view(<azimuth>, <elevation>) % azimute = angle from -y axis to proj onto xy-plane, elevation = angle from xy plane to z axis % below are for surfaces only shading <shade> % options: flat,faceted,interp colormap <map> % options: default,parula,turbo,hsv,hot,cool,spring,summer,autumn,winter,gray,bone,copper,pink,sky,abyss,jet,lines,colorcube,prism,flag,white colorbar Line properties: plot3(x, y, z, ... item.title: Python numpy
item.description:
import numpy as np v = np.array(list) # turns list into a numpy array v[[0,1]] # first 2 entries v[start:stop] # not including <stop> v[start:] # until last entry v[:end] # from the first entry v[:] # all entries A = np.array([1,0],[0,1]) # 2D array is matrix A[i,j] # returns i,j entry, zero-indexed A[[i1,i2],[j1,j2,j3]] # etc. A[:,j] # j-th column **AS AN ARRAY**, not column vector A[i,:] # i-th row A.shape # returns the dimension of the array, use A.shape[0/1] for row/col v.dtype # returns the datatype v.astype(int) # converts datatypes

import numpy as np np.random.rand() # random number from uniform distribution np.random.randn(n) # array of n random numbers np.zeros((2,3,4)) # 2x4x3 array of zeros np.ones((3,2)) # 3x2 array of zeros np.arange(n) # same as np.array(range(n)) np.linspace(start,stop,num) np.vstack((A,B)) np.hstack((A,B)) np.reshape(m,n) # mxn matrix A+B A-B A*B A/B A**B # pointwise np.sqrt(A) np.exp(A) np.log(A) np.abs(A) np.sign(A) # pointwise A@B = np.dot(A,B) # matrix multipication A.T = A.transpose() = np.transpose(A) # transpose A.real # real part A.sum() = np.sum(A) # sum of entries A.min() = np.min(A) # min of entries A.max() = np.max(A) # max of entries A.std() = np.std(A) # standard deviation A.mean() = np.mean(A) # mean of all entries A.mean(axis=k) # take mean of k-th index (outermost) A.mean(axis=0) # array of means of columns A.mean(axis=1) # array of means of rows from numpy.linalg import inv inv(A) = np.linalg.inv(A) # inverts matrix from numpy.linalg import norm norm(v) = np.linalg.norm(v) # 2-norm

item.title: Python pandas
item.description:
import pandas as pd vals = np.array(...) # the values of the dataframe rows = [1,2,3,4] # row names cols = ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd'] # column names df = pd.DataFrame(vals, index=rows, columns=cols) # generates the dataframe data = {'a':[...], 'b':[...], 'c':[...]} df = pd.DataFrame(data) # generates the dataframe with [0,1,2,...] as row names and data.keys() as column names df = pd.Dataframe(data, columns=['a','c'],index=[1,2,3,4]) df = pd.read_csv('name.csv',sep=';') df = pd.read_csv('name.csv',delimiter='\t') df = pd.read_excel('name.xlsx') Now consider: df = pd.DataFrame({ 'color': ['red','yellow'], 'size': ['small', 'large']}) df_onehot = pd.get_dummies(df) # performs one-hot encoding # columns include color_red, color_yellow, size_small, size_large df_onecol = pd.get_dummies(df, columns=['color']) # performs one-hot encoding on some columns # columns include color_red, color_yellow df_all = pd.Dataframe.join(df1, df2) # concatenates two dataframes

import pandas as pd df['key'] = df.key # gives the column named "key" df.loc[i] # gives the row named "i" display(df) # displays the dataframe df.describe() # gives a statistical summary, including count, mean, std, min, LQ, median, UQ, max df.head() # gives first 5 rows only df.plot() # plots the dataframe, each column against the row index df.plot.bar() # bar graph

import pandas as pd df.dropna() # deletes NaN entries df.fillna(num) # converts all NaN to num\ df.fillna({'col1':10, 'col2':20}) # converts all NaN in col1 to 10 etc. df.fillna(method='ffill') # forward fill: progagates last valid data point df.fillna(method='bfill') # backward fill: use next valid data point df.drop_duplicates()
